annotation.TEXT: While the idea of doing a color-spectrum level is pretty neat, this one doesn't really execute it well. As implied before, there are so many enemies here that it detracts from any significant details the stage layout may have had to offer (and while granted, it's a nice touch that the enemies are color coordinated with the backgrounds, it still doesn't excuse the sheer amount of them).

Before moving on to Tier 2, there's a minor detail to note on in the hub world: Mainly, the inclusion of NPC Robot Masters. They show up periodically after you beat certain levels. Sometimes they offer you advice and hints, though a good portion of them just have quips and jokes.
As for this level, there's virtually almost nothing to comment on. It's a pretty basic configuration of enemies with SMB2 level graphics set to Kirby music. That's about all there is to say.

This is probably my least favorite level that Tier 2 has to offer. It has the same problems as all the previous ones (it's lengthy, has a rather bland layout at times, and is over-crowded with enemies). The only thing it really has going for it is the usage of multiple paths, but that really doesn't help when each of them are flooded with enemies and nothing else. Also, the music is...ehhh, I've heard worse, but this track gets dull in a hurry. A pretty accurate representation of Tier 2 as a whole, now that I think about it.

I'll be honest: I don't like this version of Dagger Man, if only due to my own instincts. Coming from someone who spent a lot of time fighting against the original version as a beta-tester for SFR, this re-creation obviously doesn't have the same timing on his attacks. The pattern for the original is so hard-wired into my brain that I can't get used to this one (the splitting dagger move in particular threw me off, seeing as it's much faster here, and he uses it four times instead of three).

The only thing I might buy from Eddie's shop is the buster upgrade. The Proto Costume is just a cosmetic change, while the Energy Balancer and Item Drop Upgrade are a bit trivial in my view (seeing as your weapons refill after completing or exiting a stage). Meanwhile, the damage/invincibility frames upgrade strikes me as too risky to be worth investing in.

Beyond that, I have some plans for doing another Mega Man fan-game, although it'll be done quite differently than usual. I won't give away any details just yet, but I will say this: The game in question is one that I've attributed to being within the upper echelons of the worst MM fan-games out there (and just to note: I've actually called it as such in writing before, so feel free to take your guesses as to what it could be).

Unlike Tier 1 (which was bad in an interesting way), Tier 2 is pretty dull. So much in fact, that I have barely anything to say about most of these stages. A good portion of them boil down to rather generic level and enemy layouts, while some go for the "deluxe enemy spam sandwich" approach. This level ("Chroma Key") goes for the second option.

This is the part where things actually get somewhat interesting (if only in a minor way, though). There are several destructible walls in this game's engine, one for each weapon. All of them get used here at least once, which (probably unintentionally) serves as a decent demonstration for what weapons effect what obstacles. For the most part though, you'll want to remember these for one particular stage in Tier 3.

And maybe it's just bad luck, but this Dagger Man seems to have an annoying habit of appearing right on top of Mega Man after certain attacks (which is now giving me very bad flashbacks to Z Man from Rockman Infinity).

This level is about as interesting as the Tier 2 levels get, and it's only really due to the second half. The first half isn't anything noteworthy, as it's basically more of the same uninteresting enemy and level layout that Tier 2 is largely made up of.

Considering this level is also a bit lengthy, I may as well take the time to mention a few things of interest. First and foremost, there's two particular fan-games I forgot to mention at the end of the DOS Remake playthrough. Those are "Mega Man Shattered Diamond," and "Day in the Limelight 3." The latter of these is particularly interesting, seeing as Riverroad (the original creator of the Limelight series) seems to be gone, though the project itself has been picked up by another.
